bibl.note: This is a letter to Emaline Hamilton from her sister Mary. It is dated March 20, 1843. Mary starts by apologizing to Emaline for not writing as often as she should. Mary writes about going to parties and to church since she has been in Rock Cave. She mentions how some people were scared of the Great Comet of 1843. Some believed it heralded the Second Coming. She sends her love to many family members.

div1.p: I have at last taken my pen to address you, but allmost without the hope of being forgiven for my seeming neglect, of you, altho it may have appeared such, yet really it was not.

I feel as if an appology was necessary for my very great procrastination, yet I feel incompitient to the task of making one, such as you, on even I might deem sufficient, but one thing I know I can say, it is this, that if you will deign to receive this scrawl, you shall not have me to complain of in future, as a procrastinating correspondent, but rather as one that write too frequently (for you know thier is such a thing) if you could suppose such a thing were possible with me, you must therefore take the will for the deed , ⁁ for you may rest assured that I have willed you many a letter during this winter —

But I must now ttell tell you some of the things that I have
been doing since I left Nashville — in the first place, I have been trying to kill time, in the best possible manner, untill I should return to N , and then I have been going to parties and almost all kinds of frolicks that you can imagine I have received and returned a great many visits, and yet it seems as though I was scarcley half through — I have also attended church a good deal — I attended the Methodist church at Pleasant Run during the christmas week, at which place there was a considerable reveval of religion that commenced then, and has continued, ever since, Mr Redford preached there on last Sabbath, and had quite a stirring time, thar is also a reveval going on in the Methodist ⁁ church at Russellsvill —

I have heard that the people, generally throughout this county, and Simpson, ware greatly freghtened at this comet, (or what ever else it is) that has made its appearance in the west, I heard that some indeveduals in Franklin closed their doors, and wer ready waiting for the end, this comet is also to be seen in the Morning
just before day, it certainly is a very strong appearance, at all events —

mother Jimmy and my self self returned from Russellsville a few days since, where we had been visiting for three weeks, we had a very pleasant time, Susan Bibb came out with us and remained untill the day before yesterday, we enjoyed ourselves much in reading and singing, while she stayed with us,

I would fill this sheet, but the fire has burnt down, and Nick and Henry are both asleep, and it is now past eleven oclock which is time that all sober discrete people should be in bed, Mother joins me in love to your Mother Susan Miss Jane, and to the boys Mort Jim and Joe, kiss Matesy and sister a hundred times for me, Jimmy sends a kiss to both give my love to Morty particularly, and ask him if he will forgive me for my very bad conduct, and if he will I will promise him faithfully that I to do better here after, we are all well write to me soon and give me all of the news of the day
Remember me to Mr. Scoval when you see him
div1.closer: in hast untill death your affectionate sisterMaryMrs Emaline HamiltonNashvilleTenn PS I wrote this on the twentieth, but have not had an opportunity to send it untill to day which is the 22nd, since I wrote the first of this letter, I have taken a very severe cold, in consequence of which I am quite seck , but hope that I will soon get better, let me hear from you soon your affectionatemary
